In 2009, Emilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to pay for the services extended by farm helpers to increase her crop yield. Emilia is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Emilia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Duk

texts.en:
Duk M., 40, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples.

M. is a teacher of illiterate people in her village and earns an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband sells brooms, earning an income of about USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses.

M. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a truck for one of her children to use to transport workers from the factory. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a truck for one of her children to transport workers from the factory

loans.name: Dios Bendice Group

texts.en:
Ruth is the coordinator of her group Dios Bendice (God Bless), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican  clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, an area where the economy is dominated by sugarcane and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and three children.

Ruth is excited to be taking her first loan from Esperanza. She plans to use this loan to invest in her two businesses which are both food markets by purchasing rice, soup, beans, and various other foods by the dozen or in sacks to sell. She will use the profits to save towards continuing to grow her chain of food markets. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Rice, soup, beans, various other foods by the dozen or in sacks

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden M., on the right in the photo, sells bread, ice cream and groundnut phase (peanut paste) at the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes, onions, etc., to sell.

Kiden M. is 39 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock tomatoes, onions, etc., to sell

loans.name: Adodo Dédé

texts.fr: H. adodo dédé exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes, elle a entamé ce commerce en 1990 et a associé plus tard le commerce de cartes de recharge. sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes dont la plupart des femmes. elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de d'une  quinzaine de pagnes de différentes qualités et de quelques cartes de recharges téléphoniques.
texts.en:
H. Adodo Dédé makes her living by selling wax cloths. She entered into this trade in 1990 and afterwards began selling phone topup cards as well. Her customer base is made up of many people, most of whom are women. She would like to replenish her stock and so is seeking a loan from WAGES so that she may buy fifteen wax cloths of varying quality as well as several phone topup cards.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing wax cloths

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda D. T. is a widow who lives in Brgy. Maloray, Dalaguete, Cebu. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, fish selling, and farming. Merlinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past ten loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Merlinda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 12000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7500, improving the family's standard of living.  This time, for her eleventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 13000, which she intends to use to stock her general store with a bigger volume of the basic commodities that she sells.  In this way she can continue to save up for future plans for her family. Merlinda D. T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To restock her general store

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel M. is from the village of Barangay 1, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 28 years old. Maricel is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Maricel owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies like baked "siopao" and sugar-coated bananas in the local community. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Maricel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Maricel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is a member of 'Huruma B' group in Faulu Kenya.  He is married to a business-lady who sells tomatoes wholesale while he sells bananas.  He was previously selling sugarcane to earn a living.  He hopes to see his children acquire the best education.  He has requested his first loan of 15,000 KES from Faulu Kenya.  With the loan, he will buy more bananas for resale.

loans.use: To buy more bananas for resale

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en: Anecita S. is a 27-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a used-clothing business. She lives in Yulo Street, Brgy. 8, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her used-clothing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP). Anecita is now borrowing PHP 28,000 so that she can continue to purchase more stock of used clothes to sell. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 26,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Anecita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending-team page on Kiva to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Ma. Suzette

texts.en:
Ma. Suzette A. is from the village of Sta. Rosa. She is 43 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Suzette owns a business raising pigs to fatten and sell. Ma. Suzette has been engaged in her business for over two years and makes approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her grown pigs.

In 2009, Ma. Suzette joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Ma. Suzette from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Annah Jillo

texts.en:
Annah Jillo is 39 years old and is married to John Kinyimu who is a police officer. Together they have two children aged 14 and 8.  She has a boutique where she sells clothes to people in Kajiado market and its surroundings.  She learned about Kadet Ltd in a Kadet Business awareness meeting which was conducted at Kajiado market.

The boutique business gives Annah a monthly income of Kshs 4,000 which she uses to help her husband in taking care of their family. With the loan she plans to use Kshs 25,000 to buy clothes for selling and the other Kshs 25,000 to rent and open a shop in Kitengela town where there are more customers.

She intends to grow her business to wholesale with the extra money generated from the business.

Annah describes herself as enterprising.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale and open a second shop.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert M. is 44 years old and a father of five.  He has been running a restaurant in Bwombaso-Rukungiri for the past decade.  His business brings in 260,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) per month.  Robert plans to use his loan to restock his restaurant with more food supplies.

loans.use: The purchase more food supplies for his restaurant

loans.name: Zarina's Group

texts.en:
Zarina makes beautiful embroidered clothes to earn an income for her family. She learned this art from her mother as a teenager.

Zarina and her family live a in a small housing colony named Arshad, in a three room brick home in the city of Riwind, Pakistan.  It is famous for its dairy industry. Her husband buys candy at wholesale prices and sells to shop owners for a profit. 

She is the mother of three sons and two daughters.  She couldn’t provide an education to her sons and they started working as teenagers.  Her daughters are in school.

Zarina has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to provide financial assistance to her husband.  He will utilize the loan to purchase more candy. He has been in business for seven years and Zarina is hopeful that a loan will improves the financial condition of their family. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application.  Zarina has built a good credit history and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: To buy candies to sell

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon O. is a married man who lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

He has operated a vegetable stall business for the past two years, selling from home to his neighbors and passersby. Simon faces a major challenge of seasonality and fluctuation of prices in the market. He hopes to expand his business and establish a retail shop in the future.

With the 20000 KES he wants to purchase green vegetables, tomatoes, onions and fruits. He decided to join Yehu because of the efficiency of the financial services.

loans.use: To purchase green vegetables, tomatoes, onions and fruits

loans.name: Luis Enrique

texts.es:
Luis Enrique Y. N. tiene 30 años de edad, Es soltero, vive con los hermanos  en  el  Cantón de Moncache  Provincia los Ríos. No tiene hijos. 

Los miembros de la V.R.C. 27 DE OCTUBRE   se encuentra ubicada  en el recinto Santa Sofía, Todos los socios se dedican al cultivo de ciclo corto especialmente siembran maíz, arroz y fréjol gandul, esta actividad llevan mucho tiempo haciéndolo.

Luis Enrique se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz y arroz y fréjol gandul. Compra sus productos en el Comercial Briones  y vende los  productos en el Comercial Vaca y García.

Solicita el crédito para la comprar de insumos agrícolas y fertilizantes para el cultivo de maíz y arroz y fréjol gandul. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es comprar una finca y comprar una casa.

Le gusta el deporte.
texts.en:
Luis Enrique Y. N. is 30 years old.  He is single and lives with his siblings in the canton of Moncache, which is in Ríos province.  He does not have any children.

The members of the "27th of October" rural communal bank are based in the precinct of Santa Sofía.  All of the members work in short-cycle agriculture, planting corn, rice, and pigeon peas.  Collectively, they have many years of experience in this activity.

Luis Enrique plants corn, rice, and pigeon peas. He buys products in the Briones market and sells what he produces in the Vaca y Garcia market.

He is requesting this loan to buy agricultural supplies and fertilizers for cultivating corn, rice, and pigeon peas.  With the economic support provided by this loan, he will be better able to meet his needs.  He faces challenges like insect plagues, crop illnesses, and variations in the climate.  His dream is to buy a farm and his own house.

He enjoys sports.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Mr. Pen Bros Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of thirteen people in Thnoas village in Takeo province. They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve their families'  living.
Mr. Pen B. is a village bank president who has been selected by the other members. He was born in 1972. He is a widower with four children, three of whom are studying in local public school, but the other one is too small to work or study. He is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell in order to support his family.   Besides farming, he is a laborer and rock breaker, too. He does very hard work, and yet he can earn only a little income. So Mr. Pen B. is applying for a loan to buy two piglets for breeding as well as pig food, to start a new business.  With the rest of the  loan, he is going to pay his children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy two piglets and pig food, for breeding
